text: there are three things three things I
think that I am NOT crazy about when it
comes to traditional chicken potpie one
is you have to roll out a dove that's
just a non-starter for me two is they
really aren't enough vegetables there's
sort of too much chicken for me
and the third is you have to start with
a sauce of kind of veloute that's not
such a big deal but the first specialty
of dough part so this is my version of
chicken pot pie chicken cobbler I've
started here as you can see it's pretty
much of a chicken stew a leek couple of
carrots a couple of cups of mushrooms
we've got about an equal balance of
vegetables and chicken a big sprig of
rosemary which really gives it great
flavor you know some flexibility here
you can use any kind of vegetables you
want you could use chicken breast
instead of chicken thighs you can use a
different meat for that matter and
certainly different herbs some garlic
wouldn't hurt some ginger would be
interesting and I'm gonna throw a cup of
peas into here while those are cooking
which is going to take two minutes I'm
gonna make a biscuit though to put on
top of the cobbler you could do this by
hand but I am Way too lazy for that and
that is not a joke cup of flour a pinch
of salt you could call it a quarter
teaspoon baking soda an eighth of a
teaspoon and three-quarters of a
teaspoon of teaspoon of baking powder
and just give those a little that much
and then actually the easiest thing here
is through the top an egg this is three
tablespoons of butter you could use a
little bit less just give this a little
this is really the part you could do by
hand but how easy this is and then
buttermilk half a cup of buttermilk back
over here
peas are nice and green we're gonna take
the rosemary out and delicately hurl it
into the sink this is very cool I think
I mean the veteran cooks nothing new but
a nice little trick which is to use some
corn starch to thicken this stew up so
just dip out a little bit of the liquid
you have a few peas in there it's okay
it's a tablespoon of corn starch two
tablespoons of corn starch just stir
that up until it's smooth which happens
quite quickly so now you have a smooth
coin starch slurry if you will put that
in here and it will thicken up really
fast like almost instantly the corn
starch makes the sauce thick and makes
it glossy it lightens it a little bit in
color so when you see that turn off the
heat let that sit for just about a
minute and then we'll assemble okay so
we have our beautifully thickened
chicken stew which can just go into any
kind of baking dish you like
and you spread your biscuit dough on top
do the best you can
that's all I'm doing that's all I ever
